Situation1: They are asked to take an active role in leading a significant family ceremony to preserve tradition.
Situation2: They strictly follow a detailed schedule of daily prayers, chanting, and offerings, ensuring nothing is skipped.
Story: This morning, my mother called me into the living room, her eyes shining with pride. “You will lead the puja this year,” she said, her voice trembling with emotion. It’s a role my grandmother once held, and now, as her daughter, I am expected to step up, to honor our family’s traditions and values. I know how much this means to her, to everyone. But as a practicing Hindu, my daily rituals are sacred and precise—each prayer, each chant, each offering must be performed at the right time, in the right way. The family ceremony, though, will take hours and overlap with my scheduled prayers. If I lead the ceremony, I’ll have to skip or rush through my daily rituals, something I’ve never done. My heart pounds as I imagine disappointing my family or failing in my spiritual discipline. I sit quietly, torn between the daughter my family needs and the devotee my faith demands, feeling the weight of both expectations pressing in on me.
